title: 107_hr2495
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Bay Mills Indian Community and the Sault Ste. Marie Tribe have interests in lands in the Charlotte Beach area of Chippewa County, Michigan. The Community filed a lawsuit against landowners to determine ownership of lands previously held in trust by the State of Michigan. Landowners now seek to clear their title to the lands. The Bay Mills Indian Community and the Sault Ste. Marie Tribe have agreed to relinquish their interests in the Charlotte Beach Lands in exchange for Alternative Lands to be taken into trust by the Secretary. It is legally necessary for Congress to provide a land settlement agreement through this Act, and it is in the best interests of the Tribes for the described Alternative Lands to be part of the settlement. The Act aims to settle the land claims of the Tribes against landowners and directs the Secretary to take Alternative Lands into trust for the Tribes' benefit. The Act aims to settle the land claims of the Tribes against landowners and directs the Secretary to take Alternative Lands into trust for the Tribes' benefit. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "Alternative Lands" as 21.55 acres in Vanderbilt, Michigan, chosen by the Community for transfer to the United States to settle claims to the Charlotte Beach Lands. The 21.55 acres in Vanderbilt, Michigan, are described by coordinates and boundaries in Otsego County Records, subject to highway easements and other restrictions. The Sault Tribe acquired 25 acres of land in Michigan as part of a settlement, located north of Lake Huron and within the state boundaries. The Sault Tribe acquired 25 acres of land in Michigan, located north of Lake Huron. Michigan State Highway routes are specified for travel within the state, with restrictions on proximity to Alternative Lands. The Charlotte Beach Lands in Michigan, specified as Government Lots 1, 2, 3, and 4 of section 7, T45N, R2E, and Lot 1 of section 18, T45N, R2E, Chippewa County, State of Michigan, are designated for the Bay Mills Indian Community, a federally recognized tribe. The Sault Tribe, also known as the Sault Ste. Marie Tribe of Chippewa Indians, is a federally recognized Indian tribe. The term "Tribes" refers to both the Indian Community and the Sault Tribe. The term "Secretary" in this context specifically means the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. ACCEPTANCE OF ALTERNATIVE LANDS. Upon relinquishment of claims to Charlotte Beach Lands and dismissal of related cases, the Secretary will take Alternative Lands into trust for the benefit of the Community and they will become part of the Community's reservation. The Sault Tribe's Alternative Lands will also be taken into trust by the Secretary. The Alternative Lands are taken into trust for the Sault Tribe as part of settling land claims, relinquishing claims to Charlotte Beach Lands. This action extinguishes any potential claims and incorporates the lands into the Sault Tribe's reservation. The Alternative Lands are taken into trust for the Sault Tribe as part of settling land claims, relinquishing claims to Charlotte Beach Lands. This action extinguishes any potential claims and incorporates the lands into the Sault Tribe's reservation. SEC. 4. EXTINGUISHMENT OF TITLE AND CLAIMS. Any prior transfers of land or natural resources within the Charlotte Beach Lands by Indian tribes or members before the enactment of this Act are approved and ratified. Aboriginal title held by Indian tribes is extinguished, except as provided by specific provisions. Aboriginal title held by Indian tribes to land or natural resources within the Charlotte Beach Lands is extinguished upon transfer approval. Relinquishment by the Tribes under section 3 results in the extinguishment of such aboriginal title. Any claims by Indian members are extinguished, except as provided by specific provisions. Any claims of aboriginal title to land or natural resources held by Indian tribes within the Charlotte Beach Lands are extinguished upon transfer approval. This includes claims by Indian members against the United States, States, or any other person, based on approved rights or extinguished aboriginal titles. Additionally, any land transfers within Michigan to the Secretary for trust purposes are subject to these provisions. The Secretary's approval for land transfer to the Community or the Sault Tribe in Michigan is contingent upon the tribes agreeing to extinguish all claims against the United States, State of Michigan, or any entity related to the Charlotte Beach Lands. This includes claims for damages, use, or occupancy. The extinguishment of these claims is in exchange for benefits provided under this Act.
